text: <http://www.seriouseats.com/2016/10/beyond-burger-impossible-burger-vegan-taste-test.html>

attachments.title: Let It Bleed (Humanely): We Taste the Vegan "Impossible" and "Beyond" Burgers
attachments.text: The last few years have been exciting times for veggie burgers, with two extraordinarily well-funded companies—Beyond Meat and Impossible Foods—releasing plant-based burgers that they claim not only smell and taste like meat but look, handle, and cook like meat as well. I tend to want to taste something for myself before I believe the hype, and, over the last couple of weeks, I've managed to have both of these burgers multiple times. Here are my thoughts.
attachments.fallback: Let It Bleed (Humanely): We Taste the Vegan "Impossible" and "Beyond" Burgers

text: ^ As a vegetarian, I never understood the appeal. I guess for people with high blood pressure who need to go vegan for health reasons?
I think these things are targeted toward people in transition, or toward people who are averse to vegetarian food but still care about the environmental costs of meet
he outlines several reasons that i tend to agree with. When I was vegetarian for 10 years, I did crave meat and sought out meat substitutes- there are vegs who like the taste
I think that its also interesting for people that DO eat meat but want to reduce their environmental impact
^ this speaks to me
I fall into that latter category too
So find these development to be super interesting
I also like vegetarian food but dislike when food tries to impersonate other food
^ Me too
But I get the reasons for other people
interesting: the Beyond burger is being stocked in the meat department, not the meat alternatives department
they are obviously targeting meat eaters

They are, the guy who started it has non-veg kids and wife (or that was true at some point in his company development), and is targeting people who feel like "real" meals include meat. Tyson foods recently became part owner, so it's not a fully vegetarian company anymore.
When I talk to people about their food choices I constantly hear that meals need to include meat
haha, that's me! I feel that way most of the time... I think it's because growing up we always had some sort of meat w/ dinner. My dad REALLY loves meat.
Tusk is so good.
:sparkling_heart::raised_hands::skin-tone-2:
PS - if you want pity drinks and food, slyly mention it's a first date night out post baby (even when it's not ;) )
